item.title: Bridging Finance Executives Receive Fines, Bans in Ontario Fraud Case
item.description: David and Natasha Sharpe, the husband-and-wife team found to have committed fraud at private lender Bridging Finance Inc., were fined and ordered by Canada’s top securities regulator to repay more than C$20 million ($14.6 million).
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin

media:content.media:description: The Ontario Securities Commission (OSC) logo is displayed on the door to hearing rooms in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Thursday, Sept. 8, 2011. Canada's main securities regulator extended until Jan. 25 the cease-trade on the shares of Sino-Forest Corp., the Chinese forestry company it said may have committed fraud.

item.title: European Gas Prices Fall as Trump Says Iran Seeks Negotiations
item.description: European natural gas fell after five sessions of gains as US President Donald Trump said Iran had reached out about the possibility of negotiations, bolstering speculation that the conflict with Israel could de-escalate.

item.title: Kellanova Slumps on Report EU Regulators to Probe Mars Deal
item.description: Kellanova shares fell in New York trading following a report from Reuters that European Union regulators are opening an investigation into Mars Inc.’s acquisition of the maker of Pop-Tarts and Eggo waffles.
item.dc:creator: Will Kubzansky

media:content.media:description: Kellanova's Pop Tarts branded products at a store in the Harlem neighborhood of New York, US, on Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024. Mars Inc. agreed to buy Kellanova for nearly $36 billion including debt, bringing together two major food companies in the biggest deal of the year.

item.title: Biggest US Oil Stockpile Drop in a Year Shows Tightening Market
item.description: US crude stockpiles declined the most in almost a year last week, signaling a tighter market for American oil just as the Israel-Iran conflict threatens supplies from the Middle East.

item.title: Stocks Rise After Trump Says Iran Has Reached Out: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street traders fixated on the latest developments in the Middle East drove stocks higher after President Donald Trump said Iran has reached out about the possibility of negotiations, bolstering hopes Tehran’s conflict with Israel will de-escalate. Oil erased gains.

media:content.media:description: Anthony Lacavera, chairman and chief executive officer of Globalive Communications Corp., laughs during the Bloomberg Canada Economic Summit in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, May 10, 2011. The Bloomberg Canada Economic Summit brings together government officials, business leaders and industry titans in energy, mining and banking to explore the way forward for Canada as it works to strengthen its fiscal position post-financial crisis and seeks a bigger role on the world stage.

item.title: UK’s Reynolds Says Steel to Be Wrapped Into Wider US Trade Talks
item.description: The UK’s efforts to secure lower tariffs on steel exports to the US are likely to be wrapped into a future trade negotiations, according to Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds, dampening expectations that such a deal is imminent.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

item.title: AWS' Klein on AI Trends & Business Outlook
item.description: Olivier Klein, Chief APAC Technologist for AWS, discusses his outlook on how trends like Agentic AI is changing model structures and application of artificial intelligence for businesses in the region. He speaks with Annabelle Droulers on the sidelines of SuperAI Conference in Singapore on "The China Show". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Mike Novogratz on a Shadow Fed, Markets, Stablecoin Bill
item.description: Billionaire Michael Novogratz, CEO of Galaxy Digital Holdings Ltd., says the idea of President Donald Trump nominating a shadow Federal Reserve Chair would be “not wise” and “very bad for the country.” He also discusses the potential impact of a large interest rate cut and the market implications of the US getting involved in the Israel-Iran conflict, and what the passage of the stablecoin bill means to his firm and the crypto market. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Novogratz Sees Stablecoin Bill Bringing TradFi to Crypto
item.description: Billionaire Michael Novogratz, CEO of Galaxy Digital Holdings Ltd., expects to see tokenized equities “for crypto and non-crypto” as he discusses what the passage of landmark stablecoin legislation means for his firm and the cryptocurrency market.

item.title: Boston Transit Operator to Borrow $939 Million as Deficit Looms
item.description: The agency that runs the cash-strapped Boston subway system known as the T is borrowing to help fund transit upgrades.
item.dc:creator: Sri Taylor

media:content.media:description: Commuters wait on a the platform of the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority's (MBTA) Park Street Station in Boston, Massachusetts, U.S., on Thursday, April 21, 2022. Some transit agencies across the U.S. are clambering to adjust their masking requirements, while others are keeping the rules in place after a federal judge struck down the mandate for such coverings on planes, trains and other modes of public transportation.

item.title: India SEBI Eases Rules for Global Funds Buying Sovereign Bonds
item.description: India’s securities market regulator on Wednesday relaxed certain rules for foreign funds investing in local government bonds, to increase participation from funds tracking global bond indexes.
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty, Diksha Rajput

media:content.media:description: The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) headquarters at the Bombay Kurla Complex (BKC) in Mumbai, India, on Wednesday, Oct. 4, 2023. India’s central bank added more firepower to its inflation-busting toolkit as the nation’s entry into global bond index is set to test policymakers’ resolve to manage billions of dollars of inflows that could further fan price pressures.

item.title: Nippon Steel Closes $14.1B Acquisition of US Steel
